## What the heck is GitHub anyway? {{< fa brands github >}}

> a web-based platform that ... combines Git, a powerful version control system, with features that facilitate collaborative work and project management.

- "Version control": like Track Changes in Microsoft Office
- "Features": will become clearer in today's session.

Free to create an account - we can add you to the Strategy Unit organisation on GitHub[^1]

[^1]: Note that some of the examples in this presentation are in private repositories, which you can only see if you are a member of this organisation on GitHub and are logged in

::: {.notes}
Note that other Git hosts are available, like GitLab and Bitbucket - but we're focusing on GitHub because that's what we use at the Strategy Unit
:::

## Basic GitHub functionality: Repositories

- What is a Git repository? üìÅ

A folder with advanced version control, which you can backup online and share with others.
Can contain code or other types of files.

- Examples of repositories:
    - [nhp_model](https://github.com/The-Strategy-Unit/nhp_model): Very code-intensive
    - [RAP_Drop_In](https://github.com/The-Strategy-Unit/RAP_Drop_In): No code

üîí Repositories can be public or private - but you should never ever EVER put any sensitive data in them, even if private!




## Basic GitHub functionality: Issues

You can add issues to a repository. Examples of how we've used issues to collaborate:

[nhp_project_information #218](https://github.com/The-Strategy-Unit/nhp_project_information/issues/218)

- Assigning people to issues
- Having conversations and an audit trail
- Referencing other issues or specific individuals
- Labels to help organise issues

[renal-capacity-model #21](https://github.com/The-Strategy-Unit/renal-capacity-model/issues/21)

- Using subissues to help break tasks down

[RAP_Drop_In checklist](https://github.com/The-Strategy-Unit/RAP_Drop_In/blob/main/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/session-checklist.md)

- Create "issue templates" for repetitive tasks/checklists

## Fancier GitHub functionality: Projects

- Like Trello, Asana, Monday, or Microsoft Planner - allows you to manage many issues in one place.
- Quite flexible: See how we use different views in the [Sprint Planner](https://github.com/orgs/The-Strategy-Unit/projects/8/views/11?filterQuery=sprint%3A%40previous+) for our workload management.
- Can also be used for non-coding task management: [Coffee and Coding Planner](https://github.com/orgs/The-Strategy-Unit/projects/14/views/1)

## Sounds great! How do I get started?

- Register for a GitHub account and let a member of the DS team know your username, so you can be added to the Strategy Unit organisation
- Start playing around!
